awd_titl_txt: Realistic Treatment of Plasma-Surface Interactions in Simulations of Low Temperature Plasmas: From a New Diagnostic to Optimization of Process Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a new experimental diagnostic and an improved computational model to characterize interactions between a material surface and a low temperature plasma, a weakly ionized gas composed of electrons, ions, and neutral atoms and molecules.  Low temperature plasmas are essential for modern life as they form the basis for manufacturing a variety of high-technology products ranging from laptops and smartphones to displays and solar cells. They are also relevant for a variety of medical applications such as sterilization of medical equipment and wound healing. All these applications are based on the ability of the plasma to induce distinct surface reactions in a controlled way. In order to optimize these applications, plasma simulations, including a realistic implementation of plasma-surface interactions, are crucial. In this project, a new diagnostic to measure key aspects of the plasma-surface interaction physics will be developed, and results will be implemented into a computational model. Results obtained from this research will also be incorporated into graduate level lectures on low temperature plasma science.

Most simulations of capacitive radio frequency plasmas (CCP) only include constant ion induced electron emission and electron reflection at guessed probabilities. Any dependencies on the incident particle energy, angle, and surface material as well as other effects are neglected. This leads to an incorrect description of the particle heating dynamic and flux-energy distribution functions (FEDF). For many surface materials and gases secondary electron emission coefficients induced by electron, ion, and neutral impact as well as particle reflection and sputter rates are unknown in the presence of plasmas that alter the surface conditions. In this project, a novel simulation based diagnostic to measure effective gamma-coefficient by Optical Emission Spectroscopy in the plasma will be developed. Realistic energy and surface dependent electron emission and reflection coefficients for different incident particle species will then be implemented into PIC simulations of CCPs.  The simulation code will be benchmarked against experiments and the effects of realistic surface coefficients on the electron heating dynamics and the control of FEDFs of different particle species will be studied.  All investigations will combine state-of-the-art simulations with experiments.

por.por_cntn:
Plasmas (ionized gases) play a crucial role in the fabrication of a variety of objects present in our surroundings: low-temperature radio frequency (RF) plasmas are used for the production of solar cells, microchips, and medical implants. Without plasmas, high-tech devices, aiding our everyday life, could not be built. In order to optimize the operation of various plasma-based applications, fundamental understanding of the complex physics of such systems is required. Besides experiments, modeling and numerical simulation of gas discharge plasmas are widely used to study these systems. However, the quality of the simulation results largely depends on the accuracy of the discharge models, including the treatment of the plasma-surface interactions, implemented in the simulations. In the simulations, the interactions of plasma particles (such as ions, fast neutrals, electrons, etc.) with the surfaces - e.g. secondary electron emission (SEE) due to particle bombardment of surfaces, particle reflection, etc. - can be described by surface coefficients. Such surface coefficients are not well known for many materials and gases in the presence of plasmas, therefore, the different surface processes are often neglected completely or treated in a simple way (by assuming constant probabilities for the various processes, neglecting any dependencies on the incident particle energy, angle, and surface material, as well as other effects) in the simulations. This project revealed the extreme importance of the realistic description of the plasma-surface interactions in the simulations of low-temperature plasmas in order to obtain correct, reliable results from the simulations - this is of key importance to achieve a better fundamental understanding of the physics of these systems, as well as to achieve better process control in plasma-based applications. 

In the frame of this project an advanced model for Argon discharges with realistic energy-dependent and material specific surface coefficients for various plasma-surface interactions was developed and implemented in kinetic Particle-in-Cell/ Monte Carlo Collisions (PIC/MCC) simulations of capacitively coupled plasmas (CCPs). This new simulation code was successfully benchmarked against experiments performed in geometrically symmetric CCP reactors (built up in the frame of this project).  This represented the first systematic experimental verification of PIC/MCC simulations of CCPs.The effects of realistic surface coefficients on the discharge operation and plasma parameters were studied in discharges driven by a single frequency and by multiple frequencies. In multi-frequency CCPs, their effects on the separate control of the mean ion energy and flux (required in the applications) was investigated in classical dual-frequency discharges operated at significantly different frequencies, as well as in electrically asymmetric CCPs driven by multiple consecutive harmonics. The simulations performed by using realistic surface coefficients to describe the electron-surface interaction in CCPs revealed the important role of secondary electrons (SEs) induced by electron impact at the boundary surfaces: these SEs play a key role in the ionization dynamics and strongly influence the discharge characteristics at low pressures and high voltage amplitudes. Important effects on the discharge operation and plasma parameters were found by describing the SEE induced by heavy particles (ions and fast neutrals) realistically in PIC/MCC simulations of CCPs. The simulations run by using realistic SEE coefficients for heavy particles pointed out the strong effect of the surface conditions on the realization of the separate control of ion properties at the electrodes in classical dual-frequency discharges as well as in multi-frequency CCPs. It was demonstrated that the flux of sputtered atoms can be controlled in multi-frequency CCPs by varying the phase shifts of the driving harmonics. A new discharge operation mode of CCPs was discovered (striation-mode in electronegative gases), new details of the electron power absorption mechanism in RF discharges were revealed. A new simulation-based diagnostic (γ-CAST) to measure unknown SEE coefficients was developed. This novel non-intrusive and in-situ computationally assisted spectroscopic technique is based on a combination of experimental phase resolved optical emission spectroscopy (PROES) and self-consistent numerical plasma simulations. This method was successfully used to determine coefficients for a variety of surface materials. An ab-initio model for the calculation of ion induced SEE coefficients at metal surfaces with a wide range of surface conditions and for a variety of ion species was also developed, providing material speciﬁc SEE coefficients to be used as input parameters for plasma simulations.

The comprehensive studies on the plasma-surface interactions performed in the frame of this project provide new knowledge on low temperature plasmas and a scientific basis for enhanced process control in various applications. Outcomes of this project are considered to be of fundamental relevance to low temperature plasma science on an international level. This is illustrated by the fact that special sessions on this topic are organized at international meetings, special issues are published on this topic in leading journals in the field, and new research projects are started by researchers in the field based on the results obtained in the frame of this NSF project.
